text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Prime Minister Kabariti urges a national consenus on the election law; the government remains attached to "one-man-one vote system" while the opposition reject it.
- King Hussein in a telephone call to Syrian President Assad condemns the bombing of a bus in Damascus and extends condolences to victims and families.
- Legal committee in parliament rejects expanding the jurisdiction of the state security court requested by the government.
- Prime Minister Kabariti meets a delegation from Israeli Arabs and expresses Jordan's "firm stance of support to brotherly Palestinians".
- Municipalities minister says government looking into the plight of municpalities which are in financial crisis.
- Kabariti to visit Oman on Tuesday to deliver a message from King Hussein to Sultan Qaboos.

- Supply Minister Sobar says most of the holy Moslem fasting month of Ramadan's basic foodstuffs are in ample supply with prices steady; says the ministry has stockpiled a large reserve of commodities to intervene in case of shortages and sharp price rises.
- 55 foreign funds entered the stock market last year and 44 million dinars ($62 million) of non-Jordanian transactions in share dealings in the last quarter.
- Jordan warns that violence could wreck the Middle East peace process.
